title: 106_hr2424
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Reserve Board Civil Rights Compliance Act of 1999". The Congress acknowledges the importance of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, specifically Title VII which protects against workplace discrimination. Section 717 of Title VII applies to personnel actions in executive agencies, including the Federal Reserve System. The Federal banking agency has authority over State banks, bank holding companies, and foreign bank operations in the United States under various Federal laws. This includes the power to remove directors, officers, and employees, impose civil money penalties, and order divestiture of banks by bank holding companies. The Supreme Court has affirmed this authority in the case of Bowsher, Comptroller General of the United States. The Supreme Court affirmed the authority of the Federal banking agency over State banks, bank holding companies, and foreign bank operations in the United States. The activities of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System constitute the execution of the law, making it an independent establishment in the executive branch. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission enforces compliance with title VII of the law. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission enforces compliance with title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which applies to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System as established in the case of Hilliard v. Volcker. The jury in the case Bennett v. Greenspan found the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve liable for racial discrimination and retaliation under title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The Board has claimed it is not an executive agency and not covered by title VII, despite the clear meaning of the law. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve has been found liable for racial discrimination and retaliation under title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, despite their claim that they are not covered by the law. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System is required to post notices about the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and provide information on rights and procedures for employees and job applicants. Compliance with these requirements must be reported. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System must report on their actions to achieve compliance with section 717 of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 within 180 days of the enactment of this Act.
